qas.question: When was the 'one man, one vote' decision?
Which amendment contains the Equal Protection Clause?
When was the Board of Estimate found unconstitutional?
Why was the Board of Estimate found unconstitutional?

answers.text: Brooklyn, the most populous borough, had no greater effective representation on the Board than Staten Island, the least populous borough

context: The office of Borough President was created in the consolidation of <a2_0>1898<a2_0/> to balance centralization with local authority. Each borough president had a powerful administrative role derived from having a vote on the New York City Board of Estimate, which was responsible for creating and approving the city's budget and proposals for land use. In <a3_0>1989<a3_0/> the Supreme Court of the United States declared the Board of Estimate unconstitutional on the grounds that <a4_0>Brooklyn, the most populous borough, had no greater effective representation on the Board than Staten Island, the least populous borough<a4_0/>, a violation of the <a1_0>Fourteenth<a1_0/> Amendment's Equal Protection Clause pursuant to the high court's <a0_0>1964<a0_0/> "one man, one vote" decision.
